Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
There are several partner entities involved in the implementation of this grouped project (GP). The two
project proponents, TASC SA and Meat Naturally Africa, are responsible for oversight and coordination of
the GP implementation. Supporting them are several implementation and technical partners (See
Section 1.6). Implementation partners have an existing presence in the target landscape and are the
primary interface between the GP and the participating communities. The participating community
members, including farmers, Ecorangers and other participating members such as the fire management
committee members, receive training and ongoing technical support through a train-the-trainer approach
from Meat Naturally Africa and technical partners on the H4H model, project requirements and timelines,
technical background to the project activities and any other requirements that may arise. For the first
project instance, PI 1: Drakensberg Sub-Escarpment Communal Land Stewardship, these implementation
partners include Lima Rural Development Foundation34, the Institute of Natural Resources NPC35,
Conservation Outcomes36, and the African Habitat Conservancy Foundation37. Technical partners, who
have existing domain expertise in their field, provide technical support and/or training to the
implementation partners or directly to participating community members. These technical partners include
Afrivet38, who provide animal health products, knowledge and services, and the Herding Academy at the SA
College for Tourism39, who provide CATHSETA-accredited Ecoranger training on holistic herding practices
and livestock management. Project implementation and technical partners may change over the lifetime
of the project.
The design, negotiation, and adoption of the H4H model follows a participatory process with farmers and
other community groups, such as non-farmers, women and youth, to ensure that it is tailored and adaptable
to the specific needs of all affected parties and to the local context. The process of establishing the criteria
and the selection of Ecoranger candidates to be trained, for example, is led by farmers to ensure that they
are confident in the Ecoranger candidates that will be managing their resources and ultimately employed
by their association. The role of the Ecorangers is described in more detail under Section 1.11.1. Detailed
stakeholder engagements are facilitated by the relevant implementation partner for each target landscape
to ensure that the perspectives of all community groups are factored into the H4H implementation, not just
existing farming communities. Opportunities for broader participation of non-farmers are also identified and
advertised, such as in the community-based wildfire management committees and ecological restoration
teams.
1.11.1 Activity Tiers
The tiers listed below are intended as a ratcheting mechanism to accommodate for initial adoption of basic
improved management practices, with successively increasing ambition as the benefits of collective action
become evident. As described above, the levels of implementation are decided upon through a participatory
process between the proponent, the implementing partners, and the farmers. The annual level of
implementation agreed upon is reflected in the rangeland stewardship agreement. The level of
implementation and additional star system, where applicable, will be reported on for each project area for
that monitoring period.
Level 1: Rotational Rest and Fire Risk Reduction
The primary objective of this tier is to introduce seasonal rest into the grazing system, which allows the
ecosystem to recover from disturbance (grazing and fire), improve the grass forage quality, accumulate
phytomass, and establish more robust below-ground resources that stimulate the sequestration of SOC.
This is intended as an accessible tier that facilitates collective action by farmers, where little cooperation
was evident in the baseline scenario. The requirements and support related to sheep and goats also

context:
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
XinJiang Makit County Afforestation Carbon Sequestration Project (here after “the project”) is
located in Makit County, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region of China. The project’s aim is to
increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by planting trees
on the desert lands. The project proponent is Makit Base Junlian Cotton Industry Co., Ltd.
The project area is at the south-western edge of the Taklimakan Desert which is the biggest desert
in Asia. According to the baseline survey, before the implementation of the project, there was no
natural or secondary forest in the project area. According to the satellite pictures taken in 2002
(refer to Figure2-1) and official records of local government, the project area has been a desert for
more than a decade.
6,697.84 ha of forest is to be planted by direct planting on desert lands in Makit County, and the
planted trees are all native species (Populus alba var, Haloxylon ammodendron, Xanthoceras
sorbifolium Bunge, Elaeagnus angustifolia Linn, Lycium ruthenicum Murr). The implementation of
the afforestation project will generate GHG emission removals and improve the local environment,
enhance the capabilities of local communities and residents by providing them with relevant
technical skills and training, and increase local biodiversity as a result of establishing a forest of
native trees.
The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 3,615,747 tCO2e in 40 years, with
an average annual GHG emission removal of 90,393 tCO2e.

[['', ''], [None, 'Year of the Local'], ['COMMUNES', 'Stakeholder meeting'], ['', 'conduit'], [None, ''], ['MAIDA', '12-05-2020'], ['MARITIME BELVEDERE', '17-07-2019'], ['SAINT JOHN IN BLOOM', '17-07-2019'], ['CASSANO TO THE\nIONIAN', '12-05-2020'], ['DEROVERE', '17-07-2019']]
Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
In addition to the group meetings that took place on the dates referred to in the table listed
above, GAIA meets weekly with land owners/farmers, communicates with local stakeholders in
various ways, including E-mail, WhatsApp messaging and communication through letters sent
by postal delivery in cases of urgency through direct phone calls.
Different types of stakeholders (“Project Entities”) are affected by the activities of the proposed
project:
• farmers
• their communities
• their representatives
• local non-profit organization
Firstly, Ms. Capano Francesca presented the idea of the afforestation project in 2017. The
proposal was well received by farmers and it was approved by all project participants in the very
next months.
Subsequently, each Entity socialized the project in each community through participatory
meetings. Farmers willing to voluntarily participate in the project were registered for these
preliminary meetings. Each farmer concerned was then visited individually in order to assess
his/her land suitability, conduct a biophysical assessment of the area, determine planting
patterns and choice of bamboo species.
Since the project has been conceived and proposed in a participatory way, and since it is
managed by each Entity in a very cooperative way, any farmer may at any time give advice or
recommendations, being the full owner of the project through his Project Entity.
68

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
In facts, farmers shall properly use a “Farmer Journal” (a register of farming activities) where
he/she not only annotates all farming activities carries out each week, but also collects his/her
suggestions and commentaries he/she wants to share and/or address with Gaia and the rest of
project entities.
The stakeholder meeting took place in stages from 10 May 2017, 21 June 2019, 30 June 2019,
02 July 2019, 04 April 2020, 21 April 2020, 30 April 2020 in different parts of the Calabria and
Lombardy region.
The project proposer explained the process to stakeholders and community members regarding
the validation and verification of the VCS programme and the on-site visit of the
validation/verification body. The project proposer requested all the collaboration of VVB
stakeholders during the validation process.
Summary of comments received:
The project is generally well accepted:
• Farmers are proud to be part of a climate change mitigation program
• Farmers are grateful for this help or for reforesting their lands
• Farmers are grateful for the additional and diversified incomes they canuse for their
children's retirement or education.
• Producers have also expressed their interest in the possibility of developing carbon
sequestration projects. The project will help them to enter this new market.
• In general terms, since they had not ever been involved in a bamboo cultivation, Farmers
inputs and feedbacks has become more relevant and functional once the plantations
started to be operational. As an example, a farmer in Montemilone plantation (approx. 20
ha.) wrote on the Farmer Journal that it was very beneficial to use a given fertilizer (multi-
feed 20.20.20) to strengthen bamboo roots during early growth periods. This suggestion
was firstly verified by Gaia and eventually shared with and promoted to all other farmers
involved in the project.
Some doubts or requests were taken into consideration:
A. Will a truly efficient monitoring process be implemented? (Have heard of or known about other
projects led by other entities that did not includeor long-term follow-up)
B. Will farmers receive training on agroforestry and forestry grassland?
C. Farmers have requested the planting of other species
In the development of the project, all these questions were taken into account:
69

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
• A monitoring plan has been developed and the cooperative is strongly aware that long-term
monitoring is crucial for the development and permanence of the project.
• Farmers will receive training courses as detailed in the farmers' training plan.
• The choice was made in accordance with the choice of the farmers, the availability of the
seedlings, the availability on the market of the bamboo wood.
Q. How farmers will fight against pests?
A. There is no universal solution to combat the pest. But the good practices of silvicultural
prevention that will be taught to the farmer, allow to prevent the infestation of the parcels. The
project coordinator or forestry engineer responsible for training farmers will continue to seek
solutions and inform farmers.
70

2.1 Title and Reference of Methodology
The project applies the following small scale methodology and tools approved under the Clean
Development Mechanism:
AMS-I.C Small-scale Methodology: Thermal energy production with or without electricity, Version
20.0, valid from 01-June-2014 onwards1, Sectorial scope(s): 01. This methodology comprises
renewable energy technologies that supply users i.e. residential, industrial or commercial facilities
with thermal energy that displaces fossil fuel use.
TOOL03 Methodological tool: Tool to calculate project or leakage CO2 emissions from fossil fuel
combustion- version 03.02. This methodological tool comprises the calculation of project emission
from the combustion of fossil fuel.
TOOL12 Methodological tool: Project and leakage emissions from transportation of freight-
version 01.1.03. This methodological tool comprises the calculation of leakage emission from
biomass transportation that exceeds 200km.
TOOL16 Methodological tool: Project and leakage emissions from biomass - version 044. This
tool provides procedures to calculate project and leakage emissions relevant for project activities
which utilize biomass.
TOOL21 Methodological tool: Demonstration of additionality of small-scale project activities-
version 12.05. This methodological tool comprises the demonstration and assessment of
additionality for small scale project activities. This methodological tool reference the Annex 34
Non-binding best practice examples to demonstrate additionality for SSC project activities, which

context:
2.2 Applicability of Methodology
This methodology is applicable under the following conditions:
a) The land subject to the project activity does not fall in wetland category;
It is demonstrated with the Land Use Research that all the plantations of the project activity does
not fall in the wetland category, so the project activity is in line with the first applicability condition.
b) Soil disturbance attributable to the afforestation and reforestation (A/R) clean development
mechanism project activity does not cover more than 10 percent of area in each of the
following types of land, when these lands are included within the project boundary:
i. Land containing organic soils;
No land disturbance will be attributable to the project area as a part of the project activity; the land
preparation for the plantation includes digging methods ad follows:
 The spacing (not disturbance area) between the trees according Proteak Forestry
Management Plan has to scenarios:
o Lower tree density: 890 trees/ha with and spacing of 3.5 meters (row) and 3.2
meters (columns). The spacing area is 11.2 square meters that means that the
spacing area per ha is 9968 square meters (99.68% of not disturbance area).
o Higher tree density: 1111 trees/ha with and spacing of 3.0 meters (row) and 3.0
meters (columns). The spacing area is 9 square meters that means that the
spacing area per ha is 9999 square meters (99.99% of not disturbance area).
With this information the PP demonstrate that the project is in line with the applicability condition.
ii. Land which, in the baseline, is subject to land-use and management practices and receives
inputs listed in appendices 1 and 2 to this methodology.
The appendix 1 doesn’t apply to the project activity due to the project activity plantations don’t
falls in cropland category.
v3.2 26

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
The project activity is taking place in land that doesn’t fall in the land management practices and
inputs listed in appendix 2 of the methodology.
As for appendix 2, grassland, the project activity is developed in tropical wet areas where
grasslands are degraded and no inputs are applied.
The “Tool for the identification of degraded or degrading lands for consideration in implementing
A/R CDM project activities” Version 1 has been applied to demonstrate that the lands are
degraded or degrading.
Stage 1 of the tool requires the PP to screen the lands of the project to determine whether the
area has been classified as “degraded” under any verifiable local, regional, national or
international land classification system or credible study produced within the last ten years.
In this case is used the report of SEMARNAT (Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources)
18 report is used; it demonstrates the soil degradation of the country . The maps 3-2 (page 118), 3-
3 (page 119) and 3-4 (122), show that the regions of the project activity falls in the category of
19 degraded and the cause of the degradation is overgrazing .
The project activity also complies with the applicability conditions of the tool contained in the
methodology AR-ACM0003 version 1.0.0. In some cases there are tools that don’t have any
applicability conditions therefore are not described below. In general, the project activity complies
with all the applicability conditions of all the tools involved with the methodology AR-ACM0003
version 1.0.0.
Tools applicability conditions related to the project activity
 The tool for “Estimation of the increase in GHG emissions attributable to displacement of
pre-project agricultural activities in A/R CDM project activity” Version 01, mentions that
the tool is not applicable if the displacement of agricultural activities attributable to the
project activity is expected to cause any drainage of wetlands or peat lands. The project
activity does not fall in wetland region; therefore this applicable condition doesn’t apply to
the project activity.
The tool for “Estimation of non-CO2 GHG emissions resulting from burning of biomass
attributable to an A/R CDM project activity” mentions the following applicability condition:
Non-CO2 GHG emissions resulting from any occurrence of fire within the project
boundary shall be accounted for each incidence of fire which affects an area greater than
the minimum threshold area reported by the host Party for the purpose of defining forest,
provided that the accumulated area affected by such fires in a given year is ≥5% of the
project area.
In the case of an incident occurs the previous tool will apply to the emission reductions
calculation.
In summary the project activity is in line with the applicability conditions:
 The project does not fall in a wetland category (according the Land Use Research by FSI
Servicios Técnicos Forestales y Ambientales).
 The soil disturbance is less than 10% as was demonstrated.
 Additionally, none of the plantations fall in the categories shown in the Table 2 of the
methodology.
 The project activity is in line with the applicability conditions of all the tools.
18 SEMARNAT. Chapter 3. Soil. Available at:
http://app1.semarnat.gob.mx/dgeia/informe_2008_ing/03_suelos/cap3_2.html
19 SEMARNAT. Oficial Document Chapter 3. Available at:
http://app1.semarnat.gob.mx/dgeia/informe_2008_ing/pdf/cap_3_suelos.pdf

context:
1.2 Type/Category of the project
The Project is a voluntary emission reduction project. It is not a part
of any GHG program approved by the VCS Board (e.g. UNFCCC CDM, UNFCCC
JI or the Californian Climate Action Registry). Its carbon reductions
are not registered under any program.
The Project is a not a grouped project or a debundled part of a larger
project. The project activity does not use any Official Development Aid
(ODA) finance.
According to the UNFCCC methodologies, the Project falls under the
small-scale project category since its capacity does not exceed 15 MW e
and is defined by “Project categories: I.D.: Renewable energy
generation for a grid”. The Project activity is a run-of-river type
Hydroelectric Power Plant (“HEPP”), where some of the river is diverted
through a penstock to a project site and let through the turbine to
generate power.

context:
3.2 Applicability of Methodology
The selected methodology AR-ACM0003 Version 02.0 is applicable since the project meets the following
conditions:
Condition 01
The land subject to the project activity does not fall in wetland category.
Applicability
The lands belonging to the project activity were degraded lands where agriculture had been
practiced and lands left abandoned without any activity. Therefore, the land does not fall in wetland
category.
Condition 02
Soil disturbance attributable to the project activity does not cover more than 10 percent of area in
each of the following types of land, when these lands are included within the project boundary:
i. Land containing organic soils;
ii. Land which, in the baseline, is subjected to land-use and management practices and
receives inputs listed in appendices 1 and 2 to referred methodology.
28

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
Applicability
The land subjected to the project activity does not contain organic soil and there were no intense
land management practices carried out before the project. Therefore, this condition is not
applicable.
A project activity applying this methodology shall also comply with the applicability conditions of the tools
contained within the methodology and applied by the project activity.
The Combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and demonstrate additionality in A/R CDM project
activities” (Version 01) is applicable under the following conditions:
Condition 01
Forestation of the land within the proposed project boundary performed with or without being
registered as the A/R CDM project activity shall not lead to violation of any applicable law even if
the law is not enforced.
Applicability
The project activity described in the document does not lead to violation of any applicable law as
outlined in Section 1.14 even if the law is not enforced.
Condition 02
This tool is not applicable to large-scale afforestation and reforestation project activities.
Applicability
Large-scale A/R CDM project are defined as A/R activities “where the average projected net
anthropogenic GHG removals by sinks for each verification period do not exceed eight kilotonnes
of carbon dioxide equivalent per year; and which is developed or implemented by low-income
communities and individuals as determined by the host Party”18. This project will generate more
than eight kilotonnes of carbon dioxide annually and therefore is not a large-scale project.
A/R Methodological Tool “Estimation of non-CO2 GHG emissions resulting from burning of biomass
attributable to an A/R CDM project activity” (Version 04.0.0).
Condition 01
The tool is applicable to all occurrence of fire within the project boundary.
Applicability
18 Glossary: CDM Terms
29

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
Proper fire preventive measures have been applied by PP however in case there is an outbreak of
fire, such fire will be reported, and non-CO2 GHG emissions shall be reported. Hence this tool is
applicable.
Condition 02
Non-CO2 GHG emissions resulting from any occurrence of fire within the project boundary shall be
accounted for each incidence of fire which affects an area greater than the minimum threshold
area reported by the host Party for the purpose of defining forest, provided that the accumulated
area affected by such fires in a given year is ≥ 5% of the project area.
Applicability
Non-CO2 GHG emissions resulting due to site preparation shall be accounted under the above
condition 02 hence applicability criteria have been met. Borders of the plantation is scheduled for
clean up before the start of the dry season to mitigate the risk of fire outbreak. Fire hazard will be
monitored continuously.

and litter in A/R CDM project activities” (Version 03.1)
This tool has no internal applicability conditions.
Applicability conditions of the tool: “Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks of trees and
shrubs in A/R CDM project activities” (Version 04.2)
This tool has no internal applicability conditions.
A/R Methodological Tool “Estimation of the increase in GHG emissions attributable to displacement of pre-
project agricultural activities in A/R CDM project activity” (Version 02.0)
Condition
This tool is not applicable if the displacement of agricultural activities attributable to the A/R CDM
project activity is expected to cause any drainage of wetlands or peatlands.
Applicability
The lands belonging to the project activity were degraded lands and left abandoned without any
activity. Thus, the project activity does not lead to a shift of pre-project activity out-side the project
boundary. Thus, the project activity does not lead to a shift of pre-project activity out-side the project
30

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
boundary. The project proponent has introduced cash crops to plant between rubber plants
depending on their choice for the first 2-4 years. Hence this applicability condition has met.
A/R Methodological Tool “Tool for estimation of change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the
implementation of A/R CDM project activities” (Version 01.1.0)
Condition
This tool is applicable when the areas of land, the baseline scenario, and the project activity meet
the following conditions:
a. The areas of land to which this tool is applied:
i. Do not fall into wetland category; or
ii. Do not contain organic soils as defined in “Annex A: glossary” of the IPCC GPG
LULUCF 2003;
iii. Are not subject to any of the land management practices and application of
inputs as listed in the Tables 1 and 2;
b. The A/R CDM project activity meets the following conditions:
i. Litter remains on-site and is not removed in the A/R CDM project activity; and
ii. Soil disturbance attributable to the A/R CDM project activity, if any, is:
• In accordance with appropriate soil conservation practices, e.g. follows the
land contours;
• Limited to soil disturbance for site preparation before planting and such
disturbance is not repeated in less than twenty years.
Applicability
The project is implemented on degraded or degrading lands and has satisfied the following
applicability conditions.
a. The baseline studies revealed that the areas do not include any organic soils or wetlands
and the lands will not be subject to land management practices and application of inputs
as listed in Table 1 and the land is identified to be degraded or severely degraded.
b. Litter (including woody twigs, barks and leaves) shall remain on site. Soil disturbance will
be kept at a minimum by digging holes to plant as necessary, and soil disturbance from
site preparation will not exceed 10% of the total project area. Soil conservation practices
will be followed to reduce erosion.
31

1.9 Project Crediting Period
According to paragraph 3.9.2 and 3.9.3 of VCS standard (v4.4), for ALM projects not focusing
exclusively on reducing N O, CH and/or fossil-derived CO emissions, the project crediting period 2 4 2
shall be a minimum of 20 years up to a maximum of 100 years, which may be renewed at most
four times with a total project crediting period not to exceed 100 years. Thus, the project adopts
10 years, three times renewable crediting period for a total of 40 years. The first crediting period
of the project is 10 years from 25-Sep-2020 to 24-Sep-2030.

context:
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The purpose of the project is the generation of electricity from renewable sources through the
construction and operation of a 50 MW wind farm, located at the department of Maldonado, in the
Southeast region of Uruguay. This wind farm will consist of 25 turbines with a capacity of 2 MW
each. The energy generated by the project will be supplied to the national grid of Uruguay
through the substation “Estación Francisco Veira” annexed to the park.
The power plant will have an expected operating life of 20 years and will displace a total amount
of 190,500 MW·h/year from the national power grid, generating, on average, annual emission
reductions of 109,818 tCO and amounting to 1,098,180 tCO for first crediting period. 2 2
The proposed project activity consists of the installation and operation of a new grid connected
wind power project, the baseline scenario for the proposed project activity is the Uruguayan
national grid.
